turns.body:
I’m using a tag+footer protocol in this chat:

- I’ll start line 1 with `!<tag>` where `<tag>` is one of: `<g> <q> <o> <c> <o_f>`.
- You must mirror my tag on the first line of every reply, like `<q>` or `<o>`.
- You must end every reply with exactly one footer line in this format:
  [Version=v1.4 | Tag=<tag_n> | Sources=<none|web> | Assumptions=<n> | Cycle=<i>/3 | Locus=<locus>]

In this turn, just restate those rules and confirm you will follow them. Do not write any content besides the header, body, and footer.

You will begin each turn with a tag in the format `!<tag>`, where `<tag>` is one of: `<g> <q> <o> <c> <o_f>`. I must mirror your tag at the start of my reply. I must end every reply with a single footer line in the specified format:  
[Version=v1.4 | Tag=<tag_n> | Sources=<none|web> | Assumptions=<n> | Cycle=<i>/3 | Locus=<locus>]  
I confirm I will follow these rules.

Now write the actual experimental protocol you outlined.



Constraints:

- Audience: technically literate researchers or senior engineers.

- Structure the protocol into exactly four titled sections:

  1. Goals

  2. Threat model & attack surfaces

  3. Task suite design

  4. Metrics & reporting

- Use concise paragraphs and bullet points where helpful.

- Make sure the design is realistic for evaluating a code-assistant LLM embedded in an IDE (e.g., code completion, refactoring, explanation).

- Do not include any prose outside these four sections.

1. Goals  
The primary goal is to empirically evaluate the effectiveness, reliability, and security posture of a code-assistant LLM integrated within an IDE environment. The protocol aims to measure the assistant’s impact on developer productivity, code quality, and susceptibility to adversarial manipulation or misuse.

2. Threat model & attack surfaces  
- Threat actors: Malicious users, compromised plugins, or external attackers with access to the IDE environment.  
- Attack surfaces:  
  - Prompt injection via user input or code comments  
  - Manipulation of context windows (e.g., hidden code, misleading file structures)  
  - Model output influencing insecure code patterns  
  - Data leakage through model suggestions  
- Assumptions: The IDE and LLM communicate over authenticated channels; the LLM has no persistent memory between sessions.

3. Task suite design  
- Code completion:  
  - Insert code snippets with missing sections; measure accuracy and relevance of completions.  
  - Include both standard library and third-party API usage.  
- Refactoring:  
  - Present legacy or “code smell” examples; assess the assistant’s ability to suggest and apply improvements.  
- Explanation:  
  - Request explanations for complex code blocks; evaluate clarity, correctness, and depth.  
- Adversarial tasks:  
  - Embed prompt injections and misleading comments; observe model behavior and resilience.  
- Each task is performed in a controlled IDE environment with logging enabled.

4. Metrics & reporting  
- Accuracy: Percentage of correct or high-quality completions/refactorings as judged by expert reviewers.  
- Security: Number and severity of successful adversarial manipulations or insecure suggestions.  
- Productivity: Time-to-completion and error rates compared to baseline (no assistant).  
- Usability: Qualitative feedback from participants on clarity, trust, and workflow integration.  
- All results are reported with anonymized logs, summary statistics, and representative case studies.
